title: European Young Conservatives
text:
The European Young Conservatives (EYC) is a grouping of <a href="youth%20wing">youth wing</a>s of <a href="conservative">conservative</a> and <a href="centre-right">centre-right</a> political parties in Europe.
As of 2014, the group has a membership of 25 political youth organisations from 22 different countries and territories, in addition to four associated members. The EYC is independent and not affiliated with any <a href="European%20political%20party">European political party</a>, but maintains a non-exclusive relationship with the <a href="Alliance%20of%20Conservatives%20and%20Reformists%20in%20Europe">Alliance of Conservatives and Reformists in Europe</a> (formerly known as the "European Conservatives and Reformists").
The EYC is a full member of the <a href="International%20Young%20Democrat%20Union">International Young Democrat Union</a>.
History.
The EYC was founded in August 1993 by the youth wings of the British <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Conservative Party</a>, Danish <a href="Conservative%20People%27s%20Party%20%28Denmark%29">Conservative People's Party</a>, and Icelandic <a href="Independence%20Party%20%28Iceland%29">Independence Party</a>, under the leadership of <a href="Andrew%20Rosindell">Andrew Rosindell</a>, then-chairman of the UK's <a href="Young%20Conservatives%20%28UK%29">Young Conservatives</a>.
It emerged from a split in the centre-right <a href="Democrat%20Youth%20Community%20of%20Europe">Democrat Youth Community of Europe</a> (DEMYC), which separated into two factions: the larger part, following a broadly <a href="Christian%20democracy">Christian democratic</a> philosophy; and the smaller part, led by Rosindell, following a broadly <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> philosophy. Two crucial points of disagreement were the scope of <a href="economic%20liberalisation">economic liberalisation</a> and the desirability of a <a href="federal%20Europe">federal Europe</a>.
From 1993 to 1997, the group was led by Rosindell. The group gave training to newly established democratic political parties in <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>, and <a href="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>. It was refounded much later by <a href="Oliver%20Cooper%20%28politician%29">Oliver Cooper</a>.
The EYC generally holds three conference events per year, with the largest being the autumn Freedom Summit.
Annual Congress.
Since 2016, an internal conflict between <a href="Civic%20nationalism">civic</a> and <a href="ethnic%20nationalism">ethnic nationalists</a> has emerged within the EYC. The ethnic nationalists were opposed to the membership of Turkish and Israeli parties and claimed the EYC has "replaced <a href="opposition%20to%20immigration">anti-immigration politics</a> with free market capitalism". Resulting from the dispute, the <a href="Finns%20Party%20Youth">Finns Party Youth</a> announced its withdrawal on May 18, 2017, with its leader Samuli Voutila saying: "We cannot be members in the same organization as the new Turkish sultan’s youth wing, when it acts against European values." On June 12, the Estonian movement <a href="Blue%20Awakening">Blue Awakening</a> sent a letter to the EYC demanding the expulsion of the Turkish AK Party Youth within seven days. The letter was later published on <a href="Richard%20B.%20Spencer">Richard B. Spencer</a>'s website <a href="Altright.com">Altright.com</a>.
Membership.
The EYC has twenty-five member organisations:
